item.title: U.S. Climate Report Warns of Damaged Environment and Shrinking Economy
item.media:description: Fighting the Camp Fire this month in Magalia, Calif.
item.description: Without major action to rein in global warming, the American economy could lose 10 percent of G.D.P. by 2100, according to a report from 13 federal agencies.
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT and KENDRA PIERRE-LOUIS

item.title: What’s New in the Latest U.S. Climate Assessment
item.media:description: A volunteer helping flood victims in Wilmington, N.C., in September.
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.description: More and more of the predicted impacts of global warming are now becoming a reality.
item.dc:creator: BRAD PLUMER and HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: See How the Fires Burned Where California Goes to Escape It All
item.media:description: The Woolsey Fire burned down toward the shoreline at Leo Carrillo State Beach in Malibu, Calif.
item.media:credit: Stuart Palley for The New York Times
item.description: Among the blackened and charred areas in Southern California were hiking trails overlooking the ocean, summer camps and historic movie sets.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER MEDINA

item.title: A Winter-Coat Heavyweight Gives Trump’s Trade War the Cold Shoulder
item.media:description: An employee at Columbia Sportswear headquarters in Portland, Oregon uses a planimeter, which is a tool to measure the two-dimensional area of each material visible on the external surface area of a shoe which is necessary to determine the customs tariff classification and duty rate.
item.media:credit: Corey Arnold for The New York Times
item.description: Columbia Sportswear has worked around tariffs for decades — and it says the president’s new wave of levies will not bring jobs back to America.
item.dc:creator: JIM TANKERSLEY

item.title: New York State’s Lawsuit Against Trump Foundation Can Proceed, Judge Rules
item.media:description: For the second time this year, a New York State judge in Manhattan decided that President Trump is not immune from civil court cases that involve his unofficial activities or actions that took place before he was in office.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: A judge rejected several arguments that the state’s lawsuit accusing the Trump Foundation of misusing funds and self-dealing should be tossed out.
item.dc:creator: J. DAVID GOODMAN

item.title: Trump Asks Supreme Court for Fast Appeal of Transgender Military Ban
item.media:description: Solicitor General Noel J. Francisco told the Supreme Court that prompt action was required to ensure that it could rule on the Trump administration’s ban on transgender military service before its current term ended in June.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: In what has become an increasingly common move for the Trump administration, it asked the justices to step in before lower courts have ruled.
item.dc:creator: ADAM LIPTAK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: The Website That Shows How a Free Press Can Die
item.media:description: From the beginning of his premiership in 2010, Viktor Orban has steadily eroded the checks and balances in Hungary’s once-promising democracy, especially the independent media.
item.description: Origo was a popular, independent news outlet that made trouble for Hungary’s far-right leader, Viktor Orban. Relentless pressure changed all that.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY and BENJAMIN NOVAK

item.title: Jets, Horses and Bribes: How a Venezuelan Official Became a Billionaire as His Country Crumbled
item.media:description: Emanuel Andrade, the son of Alejandro Andrade, a former Venezuela official who has admitted receiving more than $1 billion in bribes, competing in Paris in 2017.
item.description: Alejandro Andrade, a former treasurer in Venezuela’s Socialist government, will be sentenced next week after pleading guilty to receiving more than $1 billion in bribes.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Fistfights and Long Lines on Black Friday? Not as Much Anymore.
item.media:description: The sidewalks of the SoHo area of Manhattan were packed on Black Friday, 2014.
item.media:credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times
item.description: Black Friday used to be all about midnight fights, endless lines and major markdowns on televisions. Like the rest of retailing, so much has changed.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY HSU

item.title: 10 of Our Best Weekend Reads
item.description: Macy’s Thanksgiving Day parade. Working while female. Notable books of 2018. And more.
item.dc:creator: KATHLEEN MASSARA

item.title: The Week in Good News: Chess in Norway, the Grammar Table, Steven Pinker
item.media:description: Taking lessons in the game at an after-school program in Oslo.
item.media:credit: Linda Bournane Engelberth for The New York Times
item.description: Sometimes it seems as if we’re living under a constant barrage of heavy news. But it isn’t all bad out there.
item.dc:creator: DES SHOE

item.title: How Loneliness Is Tearing America Apart
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.description: When people have a hole in their life, they often fill it with angry politics.
item.dc:creator: ARTHUR C. BROOKS
item.category: Them: Why We Hate Each Other -- and How to Heal (Book)

item.title: Ohio Isn’t a Red State Yet
item.media:description: A voter after casting his ballot at the Hamilton County Board of Elections in Cincinnati on Oct. 10.
item.description: But it will be if Democrats do not fight for working people in every corner of the state.
item.dc:creator: NAN WHALEY

item.title: Sheryl Sandberg Can’t Have It All
item.media:description: Facebook's chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, testifying in front of the Senate Intelligence Committee in September.
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.description: The burdens and perils of the pedestal.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER SENIOR

item.title: Editorial Observer: New York City High Schoolers Get Their Day in Court
item.media:description: High school students listen to Chief Judge Robert Katzmann, of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, speak in New York.
item.description: A new civic-education project in a Manhattan federal courthouse gives teenagers a positive experience with the law.
item.dc:creator: JESSE WEGMAN

item.title: So, You’ve Wandered Into a Too-Expensive Store
item.description: The important thing is not to panic.
item.dc:creator: MONICA HEISEY

item.title: Trying to Fight, Not Spread, Fear and Lies
item.media:description: Refugees climbed aboard trucks in southern Mexico last month to join the caravan headed toward the United States.
item.description: How can the media avoid the misinformation trap?
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Red Dead Redemption 2 Is True Art
item.media:description: An image from the video game Red Dead Redemption 2. It pulled in $725 million in its first three days on sale.
item.description: The season’s best blockbuster isn’t a TV show or movie. It’s a video game.
item.dc:creator: PETER SUDERMAN

item.title: How Democrats Can Deliver on Health Care
item.media:description: New Jersey Citizen Action in Newark helps residents sign up for health insurance under Obamacare.
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.description: New Jersey shows the way. You got a problem with that?
item.dc:creator: PAUL KRUGMAN
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: The Return of the Chastened Establishment
item.media:description: The Diplomatic Reception Room at the White House.
item.description: Who should run the country next?
item.dc:creator: DAVID BROOKS
item.category: American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research

item.title: The Beginning of the End of America’s Best Idea
item.media:description: A sign designating the Corral Canyon Park recreation area stands amid landscape charred by the Woolsey fire in Malibu, Calif., on Nov. 13.
item.description: The story told by the recent wildfires is grim, a portent of nature altered and convulsive.
item.dc:creator: TIMOTHY EGAN

item.title: Of Monuments, Arguments, Vampires and Thanksgiving
item.media:description: Monument Valley, Utah, last month.
item.description: John Wayne, Brett Kavanaugh, my brothers Michael and Kevin, and me.
item.dc:creator: MAUREEN DOWD

item.title: How Guy Raz Built ‘How I Built This’
item.media:description: Guy Raz, host of the podcasts “How I Built This” and “The TED Radio Hour.”
item.media:credit: Peter Prato for The New York Times
item.description: The astonishment-prone host (Wow!) has turned a pure zeal for business (It’s amazing!) into a juggernaut podcast. (What is that like?!)
item.dc:creator: NELLIE BOWLES

item.title: Michigan Tries to Steady That Big Chip on Ohio State’s Shoulder
item.media:description: Michigan’s Wolverines enter the Ohio State game as slight favorites on the road.
item.media:credit: Rick Osentoski/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.description: History says Michigan is better, though not recent history. With everything on the line, can Michigan Coach Jim Harbaugh fulfill his promise?
item.dc:creator: MARC TRACY

item.title: Time to Make the Donates!
item.description: In these turbulent times, charitable clicks are a form of self-soothing as well as generosity.
item.dc:creator: GRAY CHAPMAN

item.title: Jerome Corsi, Friend of Roger Stone, Is in Plea Talks With Mueller
item.media:description: Jerome Corsi, a friend of the Trump adviser Roger J. Stone Jr., in October 2008 in Kenya. He has denied misleading investigators about his knowledge of actions by WikiLeaks.
item.description: Mr. Corsi is said to have been presented with evidence that he was not truthful when investigators asked him whether he knew beforehand about actions by WikiLeaks during the 2016 campaign.
item.dc:creator: SHARON LaFRANIERE and MAGGIE HABERMAN
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Paris Police Fire Tear Gas and Water Cannons at ‘Yellow Vest’ Protesters
item.media:description: Protesters in yellow vests demonstrating amid tear gas on the Champs-Élysées in Paris on Saturday.
item.description: France deployed thousands of police officers to try to contain nationwide protests and road blockades by drivers angry over rising fuel taxes and Emmanuel Macron’s presidency.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: American-Israeli Teenager Is Sentenced to 10 Years for Bomb Hoaxes
item.media:description: The 19-year-old has remained publicly unidentified because some of the crimes were committed while he was still a minor.
item.description: The 19-year-old from southern Israel was a minor when he began his campaign of terror, which forced school evacuations and grounded planes.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: James H. Billington, 89, Dies; Led Library of Congress Into Digital Age
item.media:description: James H. Billington in 1989. He led the Library of Congress for nearly three decades, taking over at the dawn of the digital era.
item.description: Overseeing the nation’s treasure house of knowledge for three decades, he almost doubled its holdings but resigned in 2015, stung by cries of mismanagement.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT D. McFADDEN

item.title: Haitians Furious at Their Government Protest in a Week of Unrest
item.media:description: Haitians marching on Friday in Port-au-Prince, the capital, against graft, economic misery and their government’s failures.
item.description: With thousands marching in the capital, demonstrations have turned into a referendum on the administration of President Jovenel Moïse.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Poisoned Wildlife and Tainted Meat: Why Hunters Are Moving Away From Lead Bullets
item.media:description: Chelsea Cassens during an elk hunt at The Nature Conservancy’s Zumwalt Prairie Preserve in Oregon.
item.description: Many hunters are ditching traditional ammunition amid mounting evidence that it harms scavengers and pollutes the food people eat.
item.dc:creator: IAN URBINA and MAX WHITTAKER

item.title: A Guatemalan Mother Could Lose Her Daughter, Because She’s an American
item.media:description: Yeisvi Carrillo, seen in a family photo, is an American citizen who remains in foster care while her mother, Vilma Carrillo, appeals a deportation order.
item.description: A Guatemalan migrant separated from her daughter at the border has been told she faces the possible loss of her parental rights, in part because her daughter was born in the United States.
item.dc:creator: MIRIAM JORDAN

item.title: Bob McNair, Energy Mogul Who Brought the N.F.L. Back to Houston, Dies at 81
item.media:description: Bob McNair, the owner of the Houston Texans, in 2016. He paid a record $700 million for the expansion franchise, which returned professional football to Houston.
item.description: Mr. McNair, who was awarded the franchise that became the Texans, gave to many charitable causes. More recently, he was criticized for remarks about national anthem protests.
item.dc:creator: MATT STEVENS and ANDREW R. CHOW

item.title: A Man’s Last Letter Before Being Killed on a Forbidden Island
item.media:description: John Allen Chau, 26, of Washington State loved climbing mountains, camping, hiking, canoeing and seeing the world.
item.description: John Allen Chau’s letter to his parents from the Andamans lays out a disturbing account of his final days trying to spread Christianity.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN, HARI KUMAR and KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: How to Get the Most Out of Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Even if You’re Not Into Tech)
item.description: Black Friday and Cyber Monday may be known for hot gadgets and electronics, but there are great deals on other things, too. Here are a few to watch out for.
item.dc:creator: WIRECUTTER STAFF

item.title: The Morning After: Thanksgiving Cleanup Tips
item.description: Thanksgiving is awesome. Thanksgiving cleanup stinks. Here are a few tips to make it easier.
item.dc:creator: WIRECUTTER STAFF

item.title: 5 Cheap(ish) Ways to Maximize a Tiny Kitchen
item.description: Work small, cook big.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL HOLLIDAY SMITH

item.title: Editors’ Choice: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
item.description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.

item.title: What if Holidays Could Save the Planet?
item.media:description: With the 2009 White House Christmas tree, Barack and Michelle Obama ushered in an era of eco-friendly consciousness. They trimmed it with energy-saving LED lights and recycled ornaments.
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.description: After a year (or two) of natural disasters, some people are rethinking what it means to be green and charitable during the holiday season.
item.dc:creator: LAURA M. HOLSON

item.title: Rogue ‘M.T.A. Museum’ Celebrates Everything Dingy About the Subway
item.description: Using mock placards, two art students playfully reframed New York’s subway stations as a gallery documenting the city’s anthropological history.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL GOLD

item.title: Album Review: Nashville Embraces Kane Brown and Jimmie Allen, Black Singers Upholding Genre Traditions
item.media:description: Kane Brown’s “Experiment” debuted at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. The singer and songwriter has been on the rise for the last three years.
item.description: Brown’s “Experiment” and Allen’s “Mercury Lane” are two of the year’s stronger, and more stylistically conservative, country albums.
item.dc:creator: JON CARAMANICA

item.title: The Hunt: A One-Bedroom and a Sweater for the Dog
item.media:description: Josh Collins and Katara outside their new apartment in the East Village.
item.media:credit: Katherine Marks for The New York Times
item.description: To find their first New York home, a Southerner and his four-legged roommate scour Lower Manhattan for dog-friendly abodes.
item.dc:creator: JOYCE COHEN

item.title: Books of The Times: ‘The Condition of Secrecy’ Teems With Love for Language and the Natural World
item.description: In her wide-ranging essays, the Danish writer Inger Christensen, who died in 2009, cuts her towering erudition with mischief and generosity.
item.dc:creator: PARUL SEHGAL

item.title: Branzino, a Mediterranean Fish, Is Being Farmed in Connecticut
item.media:description: Ideal Fish, in Waterbury, Conn., is one of the first companies n the United States to commercially farm branzino — a species that has long been flown in from the Mediterranean.
item.media:credit: Jessica Hill for The New York Times
item.description: Ideal Fish is banking on technology to provide a fresher, more sustainable source of the popular fish.
item.dc:creator: PRIYA KRISHNA

item.title: Diagnosis: Was This Agitation Just Part of Her Postpartum Anxiety, or Something Much More Serious?
item.description: The young woman went from feeling a bit jittery to becoming completely disoriented and struggling with her words.
item.dc:creator: LISA SANDERS, M.D.

item.title: Science Times at 40: The Key to Stopping the Illegal Wildlife Trade: China
item.media:description: A child poses with a Siberian tiger cub at a park in Harbin, China. The park is part of a government effort to create a haven for Siberian tigers, but lately the country has sent mixed signals about its commitment to conservation.
item.description: The country is a critical market for animal contraband. Some scientists fear the official commitment to conservation may be wavering.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL NUWER

item.title: The Particular Horror of Long Commutes for Young Families
item.media:description: Elizabeth Yura spent hours commuting to Sacramento while pregnant with her daughter, Charlotte. She changed jobs, but commuting still takes time away from family time.
item.media:credit: Brian L. Frank for The New York Times
item.description: Traffic jams and delayed trains are infuriating for everyone, but they’re especially painful when they make you miss your baby’s bedtime yet again.
item.dc:creator: MASHA RUMER
